newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia palm oil prices seen up in 1997 - Negara.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia palm oil prices seen up in 1997 - Negara.

text.p: Malaysia's crude palm oil prices are forecast to pick up slightly this year, based on expectations of a lower supply of vegetable oils in the world market amid rising demand, Bank Negara said on Friday.
The central bank did not forecast any specific prices in its annual report for 1996.
A tonne of local crude palm oil is currently fetching about 1,285 ringgit.
The report said by end-1996, the total area planted with palm oil grew by 2.9 percent to 2.6 million hectares, while mature areas have expanded faster by 3.9 percent to 2.3 million hectares.
Bank Negara said output of crude palm oil in 1996 rose 7.4 percent to 8.4 million tonnes.
The bank said the upturn in the commodity's three-year biological yield cycle which started in 1995 had, to some extent, contributed to higher output.
The country's campaign to motivate collection of loose oil palm fruits also accounted for the higher output.
Bank Negara did not forecast 1997 output but traders estimated it would be 8.5 to 8.6 million tonnes.
Malaysia accounted for 48.5 percent of world palm oil production in 1995, followed by Indonesia with a share of 29.6 percent, the report said.

The drawdown in stocks of palm oil to 0.79 million tonnes at end-1996 after a strong expansion in production during the year, was more than matched by equally strong growth in sales of the commodity, Bank Negara said.
It did not give a figure for end-1995 stocks but Malaysia's palm Oil Registration and Licensing Authority said it was 0.68 million tonnes. --Kuala Lumpur newsroom (603-230-7510)
